$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 93
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 1310-73-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 67-63-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7732-18-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Preparation of S-Cyanomethyl S-dodecyl trithiocarbonate RAFT agent. A
1000 mL 3-neck round bottom flask (fitted with mechanical stirrer,
septum, thermocouple well, and reflux condenser with N2 bubbler) was
charged with sodium hydroxide (12.18 g, 304.5 mmol) and water (30 mL).
Isopropanol (500 mL) was added to the solution of sodium hydroxide, and
the solution was cooled to about 5°C. The cooled solution was treated
drop wise with dodecanethiol (60.6 g, 300 mmol). The solution was stirred
for 30 min at 5 °C, cooled to 0 °C, and treated with carbon disulfide
(24.0 g, 315 mmol) by syringe over ca. 10 min to produce a yellow
solution which was stirred at ca. 0-5°C for 0.5 h. The solution was
treated with chloroacetonitrile (23.8 g, 315 mmol) dropwise by syringe
over ca. 20 min while maintaining the temperature between 0 0C and 5 °C.
The solution was stirred at 0 0C for 2 h. The solution was warmed to ca.
30 0C and filtered to remove sodium chloride. The solid residue was
washed with isopropanol (5 mL). The combined filtrate was treated with
water (50 mL). Product crystals of S-cyanomethyl
S-dodecyltrithiocarbonate were formed as the temperature decreased. After
the bulk of crystals had formed at room temperature, the mixture was
cooled to 00C for 1.5 h and the first crop of crystals was collected.
There was obtained 82.3 g of bright yellow flakes after drying. The
filtrate was treated with another 50 mL water and ched to provide 8.5 g
of the product in the second crop of crystals. 1H NMR analyses showed
both crops of ca. 98% purity (93% isolated yield). Yield 8.5 g, 93%. 1H
NMR analyses.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Methods for removing sulfur-containing end groups from polymers
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Farnham, William Brown; Fryd, Michael; Sheehan, Michael Thomas
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2013062789 A1 2013-05-02

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM EXAMPLE [0016] This example demonstrates the preparation of S-cyanomethyl
S-dodecyl trithiocarbonate RAFT agent: A 1000 mL 3-neck round bottom
flask (fitted with mechanical stirrer, septum, thermocouple well, and
reflux condenser with N2 bubbler) was charged with sodium hydroxide
(12.18 g, 304.5 mmol) and water (30 mL). Isopropanol (500 mL) was added
to the solution of sodium hydroxide, and the reaction mixture was cooled
to about 5° C. The cooled reaction mixture was treated dropwise with
dodecanethiol (60.6 g, 300 mmol). [0017] The reaction mixture was stirred
for 30 min at 5° C., cooled to 0° C., and treated with carbon disulfide
(24.0 g, 315 mmol) by syringe over a ca. 10 min period to produce a
yellow solution which was stirred at ca. 0°-5° C. for 0.5 h. [0018] The
reaction mixture was treated with chloroacetonitrile (23.8 g, 315 mmol)
dropwise by syringe over a ca. 20 min period while maintaining the
temperature between 0 and 5° C. The reaction mixture was stirred at 0° C.
for 2 h. [0019] The reaction mixture was warmed to ca. 30° C. and
filtered to remove sodium chloride. The solid residue was washed with a 5
mL portion of isopropanol. The combined filtrate was treated with water
(50 mL). Product crystals of S-cyanomethyl S-dodecyl trithiocarbonate
were formed as the temperature decreased. After the bulk of crystals had
formed at room temperature, the mixture was cooled to 0° C. for 1.5 h and
the first crop of crystals was collected. There was obtained 82.3 g of
bright yellow flakes after drying. The filtrate was treated with another
50 mL water and chilled to provide 8.5 g of the product in the second
crop of crystals. 1H NMR analyses showed both crops of ca. 98% purity
(93% isolated yield).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

with an alkylating agents
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Farnham, William Brown
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM United States, US20070123729 A1 2007-05-31

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General Procedure for Michael Additions: Representative One (Entry 7,
Table 2) To a suspension of KF/basic Al2O3 (600 mg) in acetonitrile (10
ml) n-buthylmercaptane (91.1 mg, 1.01 mmol) was added and stirred at room
temperature for 5 min. Then, methyl acrylate (86.1 mg, 1 mmol) was added
to the mixture and stirred at 45-55°C for 10 min as indicated by TLC
(ethyl acetate/petroleum ether 1:4) for a complete reaction. After
filtration of the catalyst, the filtrate was washed with aqueous NaOH
(8%), and the organic phase was evaporated under reduced pressure to
furnish methyl 3-thiobutylpropionate as colorless oil. The crude product
was sufficiently pure (TLC and 1H NMR) and more pure product (93%) was
obtained by PTLC. Methyl 3-thiobutylpropionate, yield 93% IR 2956, 1741
cm-1; 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ 3.7 (s, 3H), 2.78 (t, J = 7.2Hz, 2H),
2.61 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 2H), 2.53 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 2H), 1.62-1.52 (m, 2H),
1.47-1.37 (m, 2H), 0.92 (t, J = 7.3 Hz, 3H); 13C NMR δ 172.8, 52.1, 35.1,
32.2, 31.9, 27.3, 22.3, 14.0.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM green chemistry-catalyst, Michael addition reaction
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM KF/Al2O3-mediated Michael addition of thiols to electron-deficient
olefins
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Moghaddam, F.; Bardajee, G.; Chadorneshine Veranlou, R.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthetic Communications (2005), 35(18), 2427-2433

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAS_Reaction_Number
$DATUM 31-307-CAS-14712757
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STEPS
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 93
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 1314-56-3
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: S,S-Thioacetalization of carbonyl compounds
(general procedure): A mixture of carbonyl compounds (2 mmol), dithiol
(2.2 mmol) or thiol (4.4 mmol) and P2O5/SiO2 (5 mg) was stirred at
ambient temperature. After completion of reaction as checked by TLC, it
was diluted with n-hexane and the catalyst was filtered off. The filtrate
solution (50 ml) was washed with aqueous 10% NaOH (2 x 10 ml) solution
and then dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The solvent was evaporated by
rotary evaporator and the crude product was purified through a column of
silica gel (n-hexane:EtOAc, 80:20) to obtain the pure product. Entry 13d,
yield 93%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM solid-supported catalyst, silica support used, reusable catalyst, no
solvent
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Silica gel-supported phosphorus pentoxide: a reusable catalyst for
S,S-acetalization of carbonyl groups under ambient conditions
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Shaterian, Hamid Reza; Azizi, Kobra; Fahimi, Nafiseh
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Sulfur Chemistry (2011), 32(1), 85-91

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STEPS
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 93
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 1314-56-3
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: S,S-Thioacetalization of carbonyl compounds
(general procedure): A mixture of carbonyl compounds (2 mmol), dithiol
(2.2 mmol) or thiol (4.4 mmol) and P2O5/SiO2 (5 mg) was stirred at
ambient temperature. After completion of reaction as checked by TLC, it
was diluted with n-hexane and the catalyst was filtered off. The filtrate
solution (50 ml) was washed with aqueous 10% NaOH (2 x 10 ml) solution
and then dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The solvent was evaporated by
rotary evaporator and the crude product was purified through a column of
silica gel (n-hexane:EtOAc, 80:20) to obtain the pure product. Entry 10d,
yield 93%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM solid-supported catalyst, silica support used, reusable catalyst, no
solvent
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Silica gel-supported phosphorus pentoxide: a reusable catalyst for
S,S-acetalization of carbonyl groups under ambient conditions
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Shaterian, Hamid Reza; Azizi, Kobra; Fahimi, Nafiseh
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Sulfur Chemistry (2011), 32(1), 85-91

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(2):AMD
$DATUM silica-supported
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Thioacetalization and Transthioacetalization;
General Procedure To a stirred mixture of a carbonyl compound (1 mmol) or
an acetal (1 mmol) and alkyl thiol (2.2 mmol) or ethane dithiol (1.2
mmol) in CH2Cl2 (10 mL), activated NaHSO4·SiO2 (200 mg) was added at r.t.
The progress of the reaction was monitored by TLC. After completion of
the reaction, the mixture was filtered and the filtrate was concentrated.
The residue was subjected to column chromatography over silica gel and
the column was eluted with EtOAc-hexane (1:4) to afford pure thioacetal.
The spectral and analytical data of the unknown compound are given below.
Compound 2f, yield 93%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Studies on novel synthetic methodologies. Part 39. Simple, mild and
efficient thioacetalization and transthioacetalization of carbonyl
compounds and deprotection of thioacetals: unique role of thiols in the
selectivity of thioacetalization
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Das, Biswanath; Ramu, Ravirala; Reddy, Majjigapu Ravinder; Mahender,
Gurram
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthesis (2005), (2), 250-254

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for Sulfa-Michael Additions
(Table 2 and Scheme 3). The reaction vessel was charged with ICy·CO2
(0.0063 mmol, 2.5 mol %, 1.7 mg). Anhydrous THF (2.5 mL), the thiol (0.25
mmol), and the acrylic acid derivative (0.30 mmol) were then added in
that order. The reaction mixture was stirred at 21°C for 2 h and
concentrated under vacuum, and the resulting material was directly
purified by silica gel chromatography with petroleum ether/EtOAc (7/ 3
v/v) as eluent. The pure products 2a-j. 4-(Allylsulfanyl)butan-2-one
(2h). Colorless oil (34 mg, 93%) obtained from 2-propene-1-thiol (21 μL)
and methyl vinyl ketone (3a, 24 μL). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3, ppm): δ
5.82-5.72 (m, 1H), 5.13-5.07 (m, 2H), 3.13 (d, J = 7.1 Hz, 2H), 2.68 (m,
4H), 2.15 (s, 3H). 13C{1H} NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3, ppm): δ 206.9 (C), 134.4
(CH or CH3), 117.3 (CH2), 43.6 (CH2), 35.2 (CH2), 30.2 (CH or CH3), 24.6
(CH2). These NMR data matched previously reported data.46

$DATUM 3-tert-Butylsulfanyl-propionitrile. A mixture of tert-butylthiol (9.02 g,
100 mmol) and sodium methoxide (0.1 g) was treated by slow addition (1
hour) of acrylonitrile (20 g, 377 mmol). After 2 hours at RT the reaction
mixture was filtered through Celite, followed by a CH2Cl2 wash. The
resulting solution was concentrated in vacuo and distilled under reduced
pressure to give 3-tert-butylsulfanyl-propionitrile (13.4 g, 93%) as a
colourless oil. bp 112-115 °C (18 mmHg); IR (CH2Cl2) 2252 cm-1.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: 3a. Procedure for Hf(OTf)4-Catalyzed
Thioacetalization: A mixture of carbonyl compounds (aldehydes or ketones,
1a-v, 1.0 mmol), monothiols (ethanethiol or benzenethiol, 2a-2b, 2.0
mmol) or dithiols (1,2-ethanedithiol or 1,3-propanedithiol, 2c-2d, 1.0
mmol), and a small catalytic amount of hafnium trifluoromethanesulfonate
(Hf(OTf)4, 0.8 mg, 0.001 mmol) in dichloromethane (CH2Cl2, 2 mL) was
stirred at room temperature for 5-240 min. After which the mixture was
filtered through Celite and concentrated under reduced pressure. The
residue was purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel to
afford the corresponding thioacetals 3a-y in high yields. (S)-Benzyl
1,1-bis(ethylthio)-3-(5-hydroxy-2,4-dimethoxy-3-
methylphenyl)propan-2-ylcarbamate (3x): 93% Yield; pale yellow oil; [α]D
25 -3.6 ° (c = 2.0, CHCl3); 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.26-7.16 (m, 5H),
6.59 (s, 1H), 5.72-5.52 (m, 2H), 4.98-4.90 (m, 2H), 4.16-4.06 (m, 2H),
3.68 (s, 3H), 3.62 (s, 3H), 3.20-2.54 (m, 6H), 2.14 (s, 3h), 1.27-1.12
(s, 6H); 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3) δ 155.9, 150.4, 145.2, 144.5, 136.6,
128.3, 127.8, 127.6, 127.1, 124.2, 114.1, 66.3, 60.6, 56.5, 54.8, 30.2,
26.7, 26.5, 14.5, 9.8; FTIR (film) 3359, 2928, 1697, 1594, 1505, 1482,
1453, 1416, 1337, 1306, 1226, 1107, 1045, 1026, 1003, 734, 696 cm-1; MS
479 (M+), 418;. HRMS (TOF MS ES+) m/z: Calcd for C24H33NO5NaS2 [M+Na]+:
502.1698. Found: 502.1722.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Thioacetalization of Aldehydes and Ketones;
General Procedure. A 100 mL round-bottom flask fitted with a condenser
was charged with silica gel (4 g), CH2Cl2 or hexane (20 mL), an aldehyde
or a ketone (2.5 mmol), 1,2-ethanedithiol (2.75 mmol or 5.50 mmol of an
alkylthiol), and p-toluenesulfonic acid (10-15 mg). The heterogeneous
mixture was refluxed under stirring with a magnetic stirrer. Progress of
the reaction was monitored either by TLC analysis or IR spectroscopy.
After complete disappearance of the starting carbonyl compound, the
reaction mixture was filtered through a sinteredglass funnel. The solid
residue was washed with CH2Cl2 (ca. 75 mL), or with EtOAc (ca. 75 mL)
when hexane was used as the reaction media. The solvent was evaporated
under vacuum to isolate the product. In most of the cases the isolated
crude product was found to be pure as indicated by NMR and IR spectra.
However, the impure products were purified utilizing flash column or
radial chromatography using a mixture of EtOAc and hexane. Several
thioacetalization reactions were scaled up to 100 mmol of carbonyl
compounds. Yields of these large scale reactions were comparable to the
yields reported in Tables 1-5. Compound 10. Yield 93%. IR (neat): 3436
(br), 2956, 1601, 1512, 1463, 1377, 1268, 1119, 1033 cm-1. 1H NMR: δ =
0.85-0.90 (t, J = 6.8 Hz, 6 H), 1.33-1.40 m, 4 H), 1.48-1.56 (m, 4 H),
2.47-2.60 (m, 4 H), 3.86 (s, 3 H), 4.84 (s, 1 H), 5.87 (s, 1 H),
6.80-6.90 (m, 2 H), 7.05 (s, 1 H).13C NMR: δ = 13.66 (2 CH3), 21.77 (2
CH2), 31.27 (2 CH2), 32.06 (2 CH2), 53.07, 55.92, 110.01, 113.86, 120.78,
132.43, 145.29, 147.77.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM green chemistry (- reagent)
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM A simple and efficient heterogeneous procedure for thioacetalization of
aldehydes and ketones
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Ali, Mohammed Hashmat; Gomes, Maria Goretti
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthesis (2005), (8), 1326-1332

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Synthesis of
β-Sulfanylesters 4. Ethyl acrylate (20 mmol, 1 eq) was added dropwise
(exothermic reaction) to a suspension of thiol (20 mmol, 1 eq) and
potassium carbonate (1 mmol, 0.05 eq) in CH2Cl2 (5 mL) The resulting
mixture was stirred at room temperature for 18 h. After addition of
CH2Cl2 (10 mL), the reaction mixture was washed successively with aqueous
1M NaOH solution (15 mL), water (4 × 15 mL) until the pH is neutral,
saturated aqueous NaCl solution (15 mL) and dried over MgSO4 . Filtration
and evaporation to dryness afforded the anticipated sulfide 4, which was
used in the next step without further purification.
3-(n-Butylsulfanyl)propionic acid ethyl ester 4e. 6 Obtained from
n-butanethiol (R1 = n- Bu, 2.12 mL, 20.0 mmol). Yield 93% (3.54 g, 18.6
mmol). Colorless oil. TLC (CH2Cl2/pentane, 40:60) R f = 0.20. 1H NMR (400
MHz, CDCl3): δ 0.91 (t, J = 7.3, 3H), 1.27 (t, J = 7.1, 3H), 1.40 (sext,
J = 7.3, 2H), 1.54 (quint, J = 7.3, 2H), 2.81 (t, J = 7.3, 2H), 4.16 (q,
J = 7.1, 2H). 13C NMR (62.9 MHz, CDCl3): δ 13.6, 14.2, 21.9, 26.9, 31.6,
31.8, 34.9, 60.5, 171.9. IR (NaCl, cm-1): ν 2958, 2870, 1738, 1244, 1178.
MS (EI) m/z 190 (M+, 100), 145 (19), 117 (37), 101 (64).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM stage 1 exothermic
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

$DATUM S-Butyl [bis(chloromethyl)phosphinoyl]thiocarbamate (XIc). Butanethiol,
1.2 g, was added to 2.5 g of isocyanate Ib. After 30 min, the crystals
that formed were washed with ether to obtain compound XIc. Yield 3.4 g,
93%. mp 111-114°C. IR spectrum (KBr), ν , cm-1: 1240 (P=O), 1670 (C=O),
3070 (NH). 1H NMR spectrum [(CD3)2SO], δ, ppm: 0.54 t (3H, CH3CH2, 2JHH 7
Hz), 1.04 m (2H, CH3CH2), 1.20 m (2H, SCH2CH2, 2.31 t (2H, SCH2, 2JHH 7
Hz), 3.21, 3.71 2d, (4H, CH2P, 2JPH 13.4 and 11.9 Hz), 6.9, 10.35 br.s
(1H, NH). 13C NMR spectrum [(CD3)2SO], δC, ppm: 13.20 (CH3CH2), 20.82
(CH3CH2), 30.61 (SCH2CH2), 37.82 (SCH2), 35.82 d (CH2P, 1JPC 99.8 Hz),
175.2 (O-C=O). 31P NMR spectrum: δP 27.0 ppm. Found, %: C 30.42; H 5.02;
Cl 25.64; N 5.07; P 11.24; S 11.54. C7H14Cl2NO2PS. Calculated, %: C
30.22; H 5.08; Cl 25.49; N 5.04; P 11.13; S 11.53.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Alkanethiol or alkanol was dissolved in 20-30 mL of THF (for thiols) or
DMF (for alcohols), then NaH (60% in mineral oil, pre-washed with hexane)
was slowly added and the resulting mixture was stirred for 15-20 min at
room temperature.The formed thiolate/alcoholate (from step A) was added
to a solution of 2-(2-bromoethyl)-1,3-dioxolane in THF or DMF and the
resulting mixture was refluxed overnight. The reaction mixture was washed
several times with water, brine and extracted with 20 mL of CH2Cl2.
Organic layer was dried over anhydrous NaSO4 and removed under vacuum,
2-(2-alkylthioethyl)-1,3-dithianes yield 92.5 %. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3)
δ: 4.95 (t, 1H, J = 4.6 Hz,), 4.01-3.90 (m, 2H), 3.90-3.80 (m, 2H),
2.71-2.55 (m, 2H), 2.55-2.47 (m, 2H), 1.94 (m, 2H), 1.56 (quint, 2H, J =
7.4 Hz), 1.38 (sext., 2H, J = 7.4 Hz), 0.90 (t, 3H, J = 7.4 Hz). 13C NMR
(400 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 103.5, 65.1, 34.3, 32.1, 31.9, 26.6, 22.2, 13.9.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Preparation of
1-Nitro-3-RX-dibenz[b,f][1,4]oxazepine- 11(10H)-ones 3a-r (General
Procedure).To prepare compounds 3h-r, to a suspension of
1,3-dinitrodibenz[b,f][1,4]- oxazepine-11(10H)-one 2 (1.50 g, 5 mmol) and
anhydrous K2CO3 (0.76 g, 5.5 mmol) in DMF (20 mL), a corresponding
reagent RXH (5.5 mmol) was added upon stirring. Temperatures and reaction
times are given in Table 1. Upon cooling, the reaction mixture was poured
in water (200 mL) and neutralized with HCl. The precipitate was filtered
off, successively washed with hot water (20 mL) and MeOH (5 mL), and
dried. Compound 3q was additionally crystallized from benzene, while 3r
was washed with hot benzene to remove disulfides formed as side products.
In reaction with alcohols (preparation of compounds 3a-g), 50 mmol of the
corresponding alcohol and 12 mmol of K2CO3 were used for 5 mmol of 2.
Product 3a was also prepared according to the above procedure for 3h-r
using MeONa instead of MeOH and K2CO3.
3-Butylsulfanyl-1-nitrodibenz[b,f][1,4]oxazepin-11(10H)- one (3p): mp
199-202 °C (MeCN). 1H NMR (DMSO-d6, δ): 0.90 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 3H), 1.44
(m, 2H), 1.63 (m, 2H), 3.15 (t, J = 7.1 Hz, 2H), 7.2-7.3 (m, 3H), 7.41
(d, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 7.56 (d, J = 2.1 Hz, 1H), 7.63 (d, J = 2.1 Hz, 1H),
10.80 (br s, 1H).Anal. Calcd for C17H16N2O4S: C, 59.29; H, 4.68; N, 8.13;
S, 9.31. Found: C, 59.55; H, 4.80; N, 7.95; S, 9.49.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM regioselective
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Synthetic Utilization of Polynitroaromatic Compounds. 3. Preparation of
Substituted Dibenz[b,f][1,4]oxazepine-11(10H)-ones from
2,4,6-Trinitrobenzoic Acid via Nucleophilic Displacement of Nitro Groups
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: 3. General reaction procedure for asymmetric
1,4-conjugate addition with 4f To a solution of 5 (0.2 mmol) and catalyst
QD-4f (15.0 or 30.0 mg, 0.02 or 0.04 mmol) in chloroform (0.4 mL) was
added thiol 6 (0.6mmol, 3 equiv.). The reaction mixture was kept at -20°C
or -50°C for 72 h, and then was filtered through a short plug of silica
gel. The silica gel plug was washed with diethyl ether (5.0 mL). The
filtrate was concentrated in vacuo, and the residue was subjected to
flash chromatography (SiO2) to give product 7.
3-(3-(benzylthio)butanoyl)oxazolidin-2-one
3-(3-(allylthio)-3-phenylpropanoyl)oxazolidin-2-one The crude product was
purified by flash chromatography (SiO2, hexanes/ethyl acetate = 1/1) to
give compound 7r as a colorless oil in 93% yield and 94% ee [determined
by HPLC, chiral OD, hexanes: isopropanol = 80:20, 1.0 mL/min, λ = 220 nm,
t (major) = 20.0 min, t (minor) = 18.2 min]. [α]D 25 = +75.2 (c 0.5,
CHCl3); 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 2.88-2.93 (m, 1H), 2.99-3.05 (m, 1H),
3.48-3.61 (m, 2H), 3.91-3.99 (m, 2H), 4.31-4.40 (m, 3H), 5.04-5.11 (m,
2H), 5.71-5.79 (m, 1H), 7.24-7.40 (m, 5H); 13C NMR (100 MHz, MeOH) δ
34.22, 41.52, 42.44, 43.46, 62.07, 117.41, 127.39, 128.04, 128.50,
134.05, 141.38, 153.38, 170.33; HRMS (CI/[M+Na+MeOH]+) Calcd. for:
C16H21O4NNaS: 346.1089. Found: 346.1081.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM regioselective, stereoselective, 94% ee

$DATUM Preparation of [Cp*IrCl(μ-S-n-pentyl)]2 (6). The complex was prepared as
for 4 using 12 μL of 1-pentanethiol (0.0967 mmol, 10 mg) and [Cp*IrHCl]2
(30.6 mg, 0.0420 mmol) in 1 mL of C6D6. The NMR tube was heated in a 100
°C oil bath for 12 h. Yellow solid (36.3 mg, 93%). 1H NMR (400 MHz,
CDCl3, 25 °C): δ 2.48 (t, 4H, α-CH2, J = 7 Hz), 1.60 (br s, 30H, C5Me5),
1.28 (m, 12H, CH2), 0.86 (t, 6H, terminal CH3, J = 7 Hz). 13C{1H} NMR
(100 MHz, CDCl3, 25 °C): δ 89.77 (s, C5Me5), 31.39 (s, α-CH2), 29.95 (s,
CH2), 27.13 (s, CH2), 22.93 (s, CH2), 14.33 (s, CH3), 8.46 (s, C5Me5).
Anal. Calcd (found) for C30H52S2Cl2Ir2: C, 38.65 (38.82); H, 5.62 (5.52).

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Addition of thiols to electron-deficient
alkenes in the presence of poly(N-vinylimidazole (general procedure):
Poly(N-vinylimidazole), 9.4 mg (0.1 mmol, calculated per monomer unit),
was dissolved in 5 ml of a 3 : 2 ethanol-water mixture, 1.2 mmol of the
corresponding alkene and 1 mmol of thiol were added, and the mixture was
stirred at room temperature until the reaction was complete (Table 2).
The mixture was then extracted with methylene chloride, the extract was
dried over sodium sulfate, the solvent was distilled off under reduced
pressure, and the product was isolated by column chromatography using
methylene chloride-petroleum ether as eluent. Compounds I-XII were
colorless liquids. Their structure was confirmed by the 1H and 13C NMR
and MALDI-TOF mass spectra. Dimethyl 2-(hexylsulfanylmethyl)succinate
(XI), yield 93%. 1H NMR spectrum, δ, ppm: 0.85 t (3H, CH3, J = 6.8 Hz),
1.20-1.29 m [4H, CH3(CH2)2], 1.29-1.38 m [2H, CH3(CH2)2CH2], 1.48-1.58 m
(2H, J = 7.3 Hz), 2.47 t (2H, J = 7.3 Hz), 2.63 d.d (1H, J = 8.1, 13.4
Hz), 2.68 d.d (1H, J = 5.6, 17.1 Hz), 2.75 d.d (1H, J = 8.1,16.9 Hz),
2.85 d.d (1H, J = 5.9, 13.5 Hz), 3.03 m (1H), 3.65 s (3H, CH3O), 3.69 s
(3H, CH3O). 13C NMR spectrum, δC, ppm: 13.88 (C6'), 22.41 (C5'), 28.34
(C3'), 29.28 (C2'), 31.26 (C1' or C4'), 32.36 (C1' or C4'), 33.36 (CH2),
34.59 (CH2S), 41.34 (CH), 51.71 (CH3O), 51.99 (CH3O), 172.04 (CO), 173.67
(CO). Mass spectrum: m/z 276 (100%) [M]+.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Poly(N-vinylimidazole) as efficient and recyclable catalyst for the
addition of thiols to Michael acceptors in aqueous medium
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Beletskaya, I. P.; Tarasenko, E. A.; Khokhlov, A. R.; Tyurin, V. S.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Russian Journal of Organic Chemistry (2007), 43(11), 1733-1736

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 1317-39-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 68-12-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: (Z)-Dec-1-ene-1,2-diylbis(p-tolylsiilfane)
(3a); Typical Procedure (2)-(1-Bromodec-1-en-2-yl)(p-tolyl)sulfane (1a)
(171 mg, 0.5 mmol) was added to a stirred solution of 4-toluenethiol (2a)
(70 mg, 0.75 mmol), Cu2O (7 mg, 0.05 mmol), DMEDA (8 μL, 0.075 mmol),
Cs2CO3 (326 mg, 1 mmol) in DMF (2 mL) under N2. The resulting mixture was
stirred at 120 °C for 24 h. After being cooled to r.t., the mixture was
diluted with H2O (15 mL) and extracted with EtOAc (3 × 15 mL). The
combined organic layer was dried over Na2SO4 and concentrated. The crude
residue was purified by flash column chromatography (eluent: PE-EtOAc,
50:1). (Z)-[2-Cyclohexyl-2-(p-tolylthio)ethenyl](octyl)sulfane (3hh).
Light yellow oil; yield: 175 mg (93%). Reactant: (Z)-2-Bromovinyl sulfide
1l and Aromatic thiol 2k. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 7.16 (d, J = 8.0
Hz, 2 H), 7.06 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 2 H), 6.46 (s, 1 H), 2.71 (t, J = 7.4 Hz,
2 H), 2.30 (s, 3 H), 2.11-2.05 (m, 1 H), 1.89 (d, J = 11.6 Hz, 2 H), 1.73
(d, J = 9.2 Hz, 2 H), 1.68-1.61 (m, 3 H), 1.41-1.36 (m, 2 H), 1.32-1.15

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: (Z)-Dec-1-ene-1,2-diylbis(p-tolylsiilfane)
(3a); Typical Procedure (2)-(1-Bromodec-1-en-2-yl)(p-tolyl)sulfane (1a)
(171 mg, 0.5 mmol) was added to a stirred solution of 4-toluenethiol (2a)
(70 mg, 0.75 mmol), Cu2O (7 mg, 0.05 mmol), DMEDA (8 μL, 0.075 mmol),
Cs2CO3 (326 mg, 1 mmol) in DMF (2 mL) under N2. The resulting mixture was
stirred at 120 °C for 24 h. After being cooled to r.t., the mixture was
diluted with H2O (15 mL) and extracted with EtOAc (3 × 15 mL). The
combined organic layer was dried over Na2SO4 and concentrated. The crude
residue was purified by flash column chromatography (eluent: PE-EtOAc,
50:1). (Z)-2-{[1-(Octylthio)dec-1-en-2-yl]thio}thiophene (3cc). Light
yellow oil; yield: 185 mg (93%). Reactant: (Z)-2-Bromovinyl sulfide 1g
and Aromatic thiol 2k. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 7.35 (d, J = 5.6 Hz,
1 H), 7.16 (d, J = 3.2 Hz, 1 H), 6.97-6.95 (m, 1 H), 6.06 (s, 1 H), 2.72
(t, J = 7.4 Hz, 2 H), 2.11 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 2 H), 1.69-1.58 (m, 2 H),
1.50-1.40 (m, 4 H), 1.29-1.23 (m, 18 H), 0.90-0.86 (m, 6 H). 13C NMR(100
MHz, CDCl3): δ = 134.5, 133.9, 131.5, 129.7, 127.2, 126.1, 36.1,
34.3,31.8, 31.7, 30.3, 29.2, 29.1, 28.7, 28.5, 28.4, 22.6, 14.0. HRMS
(TOF): m/z calcd for C22H38S3: 398.2136; found: 398.2133.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: 6. General procedure for Table 4. A 4 mL vial
sealed equipped with a magnetic stirrer bar was charged with KOH (56.0
mg, 1.0 mmol), Cu2 O (3.5 mg, 0.025 mmol), 1,10-phenanthroline (0.025
mmol, 10 mol %) and vinyl bromide (0.6 mmol) in dioxane (0.25 mL); for
vinyl chloride, a 4 mL vial sealed equipped with a magnetic stirrer bar
was charged with KOH (56.0 mg, 1.0 mmol), Cu2 O (3.5 mg, 0.025 mmol),
1,10-phenanthroline (0.025 mmol, 10 mol %) and vinyl chloride (0.6 mmol)
in dioxane (0.25 mL). The aliphatic thiol or aromatic thiol (0.5 mmol)
was added via syringe, and the vial was sealed with a cap containing a
PTFE septum and the reaction vessel was heated at 110 °C in an oil bath.
After stirring at this temperature for 24 h, the heterogeneous mixture
was cooled to room temperature and diluted with ethyl acetate (20 mL).
The resulting solution was directly filtered through a pad of celite then
washed with ethyl acetate (20 mL) and concentrated to give the crude
material which was then purified by column chromatography (SiO2, hexane
and CH2Cl2 or ethyl acetate) to 3 in Table 4. Following the general
procedure for Table 4, using bromomethylenecyclohexane (0.080 mL, 0.6
mmol), 1-dodecanethiol (0.120 mL, 0.5 mmol), then purified by column
chromatography (SiO2, hexane). (Cyclohexylidenemethyl)(dodecyl)sulfane
(3d),colorless oil (138 mg, 93% yield). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ= 0.88
(t, J= 6.8 Hz, 3 H), 1.26-1.51 (m, 24 H), 1.53-1.62 (m, 2 H), 2.13-2.14
(m, 2 H), 2.24-2.26 (m, 2 H), 2.60 (t, J= 7.6 Hz, 2 H), 5.57 (s, 1 H);
13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3):δ = 14.1, 22.7, 26.4, 27.0, 28.2, 28.6, 29.2,
29.3, 29.5, 29.61, 29.63, 30.1, 30.3, 31.9, 34.0, 36.4, 115.0, 141.9;
HREI-MS calcd. for C19 H36 S: 296.2538, Found: 296.2542.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES

sealed tube used

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM 2-Methyloxazole-4-carboxylic Acid Dodecanthioester (7). Carboxylic acid
16 (5.00 g, 39.4 mmol) was suspended in dichloromethane (50 mL) and
cooled to 0-5 °C. 1-(3- Dimethylaminopropyl)-3-ethylcarbodiimide
hydrochloride (9.33 g, 48.7 mmol), N,N-dimethylaminopyridine (240 mg,
1.96 mmol), and dodecanthiol (9.42 mL, 39.3 mmol) were added at 0-5 °C,
and the resulting mixture was allowed to warm to ambient temperature.
After 1 h the reaction was complete, and the dichloromethane was removed
on a rotary evaporator. Ethyl acetate (100 mL) was added, and the organic
layer was washed with HCl (50 mL; 2 M; aq), water (50 mL), and then brine
(50 mL). The organic solution was dried over MgSO4, filtered, and then
concentrated to dryness to leave the product as a white solid (11.45 g).
This essentially pure product could be recrystallised from methanol (35
mL) to afford thioester 7 as a white solid 2-Methyloxazole-4-carboxylic
Acid Dodecanthioester (7)., yield 93%, 72% 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.08
(s, 1 H), 3.03 (t, J = 7 Hz, 2 H), 2.52 (s, 3 H), 1.65 (quin, J = 7 Hz, 2
H), 1.44-1.22 (m, 18 H), 0.88 (t, J = 7 Hz, 3 H); 13C NMR (100 MHz,
CDCl3) δ 185.6, 162.0, 139.8, 139.5, 31.9, 29.6, 29.6, 29.5, 29.5, 29.3,
29.1, 28.8, 22.7, 14.1, 13.8; IR (neat cm-1) 2915, 1651, 869; LRMS (CI
+ve) m/z 312 (M+ + H).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Large-Scale Preparation of 2-Methyloxazole-4-carboxaldehyde
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

Bahareh; Vaxelaire, Carine; Webb, Michael R.; Whatrup, David
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Phthalonitriles 2; General Procedure According
to the conditions described in Tables 1 and 2, phthalonitriles 1a-e (500
mg) were treated with thiols, alcohols, or 1-bromoheptane (and K2CO3) in
molten Bu4NBr. After cooling, the mixtures were extracted with Et2O (3 ×
25 mL) and the ionic liquid could be recovered by filtration and re-used
after washing extensively with Et2O. The combined Et2O extracts were
rotary-evaporated and the crude products were purified either by column
chromatography or recrystallization. A larger quantity of 1b (1 g)
reacted with 1-octanethiol giving 2c, while 1c (1 g) reacted with phenol
affording 2i. 3-Dodecylthiophthalonitrile (2d)17d. Yield 93%. 1H NMR: δ =
7.52-7.60 (m, 3 H, ArH), 3.05 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 2 H, SCH2), 1.71 (quintet,
J = 7.2 Hz, 2 H, CH2), 1.41-1.50 (m, 2 H, CH2), 1.20-1.32 (m, 16 H, CH2),
0.88 (t, J = 6.9 Hz, 3 H, CH3). MS (EI): m/z (%) = 328 (31, [M+]), 149
(79), 69 (77), 57 (100). HRMS (EI): m/z calcd for C20H28N2S: 328.1968;
found: 328.1970.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM Ionic liquid

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Preparation of
2-(Thymin-1'-ylmethoxy)ethyl Alkyl Sulfides (6) To a suspension of 0.312
g (6.5 mmol) of 50% NaH in THF (15 mL), 6 mmol of RSH at 0°C was added
dropwise. The reaction mixture was warmed to room temperature and stirred
for 2 h, and then 0.67 g (3 mmol) of 5 was added to the reaction mixture
and stirring was continued for 5 h. The resultant mixture was adjusted to
pH = 6-7 with 1 M HCl and was extracted with CHCl3 (3 x 50 mL). The
organic layers were combined and dried over MgSO4. The solvent was
removed in vacuo and the residue then was purified by flash
chromatography on silica-gel (CHCl3: CH3OH = 20:1) to give 6. 6f, yield
93%. m.p. 122-124°C. 1H MNR (CDCl3) δ : 0.86 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 3H),
1.23-1.69 (m, 20H), 1.92 (s, 3H), 2.50 (t, J = 7.3 Hz, 2H), 2.68 (t, J =
6.4 Hz, 2H), 3.70 (t, 2H, J = 6.4 Hz), 5.14 (s, 2H), 7.13 (s, 1H), 8.45
(s, 1H). IR (KBr Disc): 3420, 3177, 3051, 2919, 2850, 1733, 1676, 1629,
1456, 1268, 1124, 1096, 947, 831, 757, 554 cm-1. Anal, cacld. for
C20H36N2O3S: C, 62.46; H, 9.43; N, 7.28. Found: C, 62.15; H, 9.82; N,
7.04.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 1314-56-3
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: S,S-Thioacetalization of carbonyl compounds
(general procedure): A mixture of carbonyl compounds (2 mmol), dithiol
(2.2 mmol) or thiol (4.4 mmol) and P2O5/SiO2 (5 mg) was stirred at
ambient temperature. After completion of reaction as checked by TLC, it
was diluted with n-hexane and the catalyst was filtered off. The filtrate
solution (50 ml) was washed with aqueous 10% NaOH (2 x 10 ml) solution
and then dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The solvent was evaporated by
rotary evaporator and the crude product was purified through a column of
silica gel (n-hexane:EtOAc, 80:20) to obtain the pure product. Entry 22d,
yield 93%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM solid-supported catalyst, silica support used, reusable catalyst, no
solvent
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Silica gel-supported phosphorus pentoxide: a reusable catalyst for
S,S-acetalization of carbonyl groups under ambient conditions
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Shaterian, Hamid Reza; Azizi, Kobra; Fahimi, Nafiseh
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Sulfur Chemistry (2011), 32(1), 85-91

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Reaction of
Compounds 12-15, 20, and 24a-d with Ethanthiol/KSCN (Procedure D). A
solution of compounds 12-15, 20, 24a-d (0.5 mmol), ethanthiol/KSCN (0.6
mmol), K2CO3 (0.6 mmol) in dry CH3CN (10 mL) was stirred at room
temperature. On completion of reaction (3-4 h, TLC monitoring), the
reaction mixture was filtered and filtrate was concentrated under vacuum.
The crude residue obtained was purified by column chromatography using
hexane and ethyl acetate (3:1) to give pure compounds 2a, 2b, 3a-h, and
4a-h.
(2R*,4R*,6S*)-2-(4-Chlorophenyl)-6-((ethylthio)methyl)tetrahydro-4-phenyl-2H-pyran-4-ol
(3e). By use of procedure D, the reaction of 14 with ethanthiol gave 3e
in 93% yield as a colorless viscous oil. UV (EtOH): λmax (ε) 220 (12580).
IR (CHCl3, cm-1): 3485 (OH). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 1.26 (t, J= 7.5
Hz, 3H, CH3), 1.88-2.06 (m, 4H, 2H of C-3 + 2H of C-5), 2.60-2.67 (m, 2H,
S-CH2), 2.71-2.89 (m, 3H, 2H of CH2S, 1H of OH), 4.22-4.29 (m, 1H, CH),
5.01 (dd, J1=8.3Hz, J2= 3.9 Hz, 1H, CH), 7.22-7.51 (m, 9H, ArH). 13C NMR
(normal/DEPT-135, CDCl3): δ 14.8 (+ve, CH3), 27.1 (-ve, S-CH2), 37.1
(-ve, CH2-S), 42.9 (-ve, CH2), 46.1 (-ve, CH2), 72.5 (ab, C-4), 73.7
(+ve, CH), 75.2 (+ve, CH), 124.3 (+ve, ArCH), 125.8 (+ve, ArCH), 127.3
(+ve, ArCH), 128.5 (+ve, ArCH), 128.9 (+ve, ArCH), 130.9 (+ve, ArCH),
132.3 (ab, ArC), 142.5 (ab, ArC), 147.7 (ab, ArC). FAB-MS m/z 362 [M + ]
(73%), 364 [M +] (23%). Anal. (C20H23ClO2S) C, H, S.

$DATUM 67-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Experimental Procedure. Thiol (7.56
mmol) was taken in dry DMSO (25 ml) and gaseous CO2 was bubbled through
it for 30 min at room temperature. To this, a mixture of
triphenylphosphine (7.56 mmol) and diethyl azodicarboxylate (7.56 mmol)
was added slowly in 2-3 small portions. Next, the corresponding thiol
(7.56 mmol) was added with constant stirring at rt. The reaction
continued until completion (cf Table 1) as confirmed by TLC. The reaction
mixture was then poured into distilled water (50 ml) and extracted with
ethyl acetate thrice. The organic layer was separated and dried over
anhydrous sodium sulphate and then concentrated to afford the desired
S,S-dialkyl dithiocarbonate. S,S-Di-4-Methoxybenzyl dithiocarbonate
(Entry 2): Oil. IR (neat, cm-1): ν = 1638, 878; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3):
δ = 3.83(s, 6H, OMe) 4.22 (s, 4H, SCH2Ph), 7.07-7.25 (m, 10H, Ar-H); 13C
NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 37.4, 56.2, 127.5, 128.5, 142.5, 202.2 (C═O)
ppm; MS (m/z): 334; HRMS: calcd. for C17H18O3S2: 334.07; found: 334.15.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM chemoselective, Mitsunobu reaction, mechanism studied, alternatively
reaction carried out using DMF, benzene, acetonitrile, dichloromethane,
hexane, heptane, methanol, chloroform and acetone as solvent
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM A high yielding, one-pot synthesis of S,S-dialkyl dithiocarbonates
through the corresponding thiols using Mitsunobu's reagent

$DATUM 75-08-1
$DTYPE RXN:RCT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 135-02-4
$DTYPE RXN:PRO(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 115429-10-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAS_Reaction_Number
$DATUM 31-307-CAS-7002004
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STEPS
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 93
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 1314-56-3
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: S,S-Thioacetalization of carbonyl compounds
(general procedure): A mixture of carbonyl compounds (2 mmol), dithiol
(2.2 mmol) or thiol (4.4 mmol) and P2O5/SiO2 (5 mg) was stirred at
ambient temperature. After completion of reaction as checked by TLC, it
was diluted with n-hexane and the catalyst was filtered off. The filtrate
solution (50 ml) was washed with aqueous 10% NaOH (2 x 10 ml) solution
and then dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The solvent was evaporated by
rotary evaporator and the crude product was purified through a column of
silica gel (n-hexane:EtOAc, 80:20) to obtain the pure product. Entry 14d,
yield 93%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM solid-supported catalyst, silica support used, reusable catalyst, no
solvent
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Silica gel-supported phosphorus pentoxide: a reusable catalyst for
S,S-acetalization of carbonyl groups under ambient conditions
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Shaterian, Hamid Reza; Azizi, Kobra; Fahimi, Nafiseh
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Sulfur Chemistry (2011), 32(1), 85-91

$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM 25.1. Synthesis of S-ethyl 4-cyano-1-methyl-1H-imidazole-5-carbothioate
x85. In a 1 I, three-necked flask fitted with a magnetic stirrer and a
reflux condenser under inert atmosphere,
4-cyano-1-methyl-1H-imidazole-5-carboxylic acid x84 (24.5 g, 0.162 mol)
and CH2Cl2 (500 ml) are stirred at room temperature. To this suspension,
ethanethiol (13.2 ml, 0.178 mol) and DMAP (1.98 g, 0.016 mol) are added,
followed by DCC (36.77 g, 0.178 mol) in two portions. The temperature
rises to 35 °C and the mixture is stirred at room temperature for 16 h.
Ethanethiol (0.0324 mol) is further added and stirring is continued
overnight. The mixture is filtered and the solvent is evaporated. The
residue is purified by chromatography on silicagel (Hexane/AcOEt: 6/4
(v/v)) to give 29.5 g of S-ethyl
4-cyano-1-methyl-1H-imidazole-5-carbothioate x85. Yield: 93 %. S-ethyl
4-cyano-1-methyl-1H-imidazole-5-carbothioate x85. Yield (29.5 g ,93 %).
1H NMR (250 MHz, DMSO): 1.37 (t, 3H), 3.13 (q, 2H), 3.91 (s, 3H), 7.56
(s, 1H).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM incremental addition of ethanethiol
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Preparation of 2-pyrrolidinone derivatives and their use as
anticonvulsants
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kenda, Benoit; Quesnel, Yannick; Ates, Ali; Michel, Philippe; Turet,
Laurent; Mercier, Joeel
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION

$DATUM (R)-S-Ethyl-4-((4-bromophenyl)(methyl)amino)-3-(4-methoxyphenyl)butanethioate.
A solution of ethanethiol (38 μL, 0.52 mmol, 2.0 equiv) in THF (4 mL) was
cooled to-78°C, and n-BuLi (1.6 M in hexane, 0.28 mL, 1.5 equiv) was
added. The reaction was stirred at 0°C for 30 min. A solution of
(R)-2-(4-((4-bromophenyl)(methyl)amino)-3-(4-methoxyphenyl)butanoyl)-1-ethyl-5,5-dimethylpyrazolidin-3-one
(131.0 mg, 0.26 mmol, 1 equiv) in THF (4 mL) was then added. The reaction
was stirred at 0°C for 10 min. The reaction was then quenched with
saturated NH4Cl (5 mL) and the phases separated. The aqueous layer was
extracted with Et2O (10 mL x 3) and the combined organic layers were
dried over MgSO4 and the solvents removed by rotary evaporation. The
crude product was purified by column chromatography using 70:30 hexanes:
EtOAc. Isolated 102.0 mg of thioester (0.24 mmol, 93% yield), 94% ee.
[Daicel Chiracel AD-H, 5 to 50% i-PrOH, 3 mL/min, 249 nm; t 1= 6.96 min,
t 2= 7.72 min]. [α]D 22 + 86.5 (c1.068, CH2Cl2). IR (thin film): 2930,
2832,m 1679, 1609, 1588 cm-1; 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.28 (d, J = 9.0
Hz, 2H), 7.06 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 2H), 6.82 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 2H), 6.52 (d, J =
9.0 Hz, 2H), 3.78 (s, 4H), 3.66 (dd, J = 14.5, 6.6 Hz, 1H), 3.62-3.53 (m,
3H), 3.22 (dd, J = 14.5, 8.3 Hz, 1H), 2.96-2.85 (m, 2H), 2.82 (qd, J =
7.5, 3.1 Hz, 3H), 2.60 (s, 3H), 1.18 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 4H);! 13C NMR (125
MHz, CDCl3) δ 197.8, 158.6, 147.8, 133.5, 131.8, 128.6, 114.0, 113.6,
108.1, 59.0, 55.2, 47.6, 39.8, 39.5, 23.4, 14.7. HRMS (ESI+) calc’d for
[C20H24BrNO2S+H]+ requires m/z 422.0784, found m/z 422.0782.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

$DATUM 950982-61-3
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 110-71-4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Coupling of
Functionalized Aryl Bromides and Iodides with Aliphatic and Aromatic
Thiols. The appropriate quantity of stock solution A or B was added to a
4 mL vial containing the aryl bromide or iodide (1.00 mmol) and LiHMDS or
Cs2CO3 (2.4 mmol) as base, unless otherwise stated, in DME (1.5 mL). The
thiol (1.00 mmol) was then added and the vial was sealed with a cap
containing a PTFE septum. The mixture was heated at the temperature
indicated in Tables 6 and 7 until the aryl halide was consumed, as
determined by GC. Silica gel (0.5 g) was added, and the solvents were
evaporated under reduced pressure. The crude residue was purified by
column chromatography on silica gel with hexane or a mixture of hexane
and ethyl acetate as eluent. Aryl sulfides were isolated in the yields
reported in Tables 6 and 7. Reactions of haloarenes bearing aromatic or
aliphatic hydroxyl groups and LiHMDS as base initially form the
corresponding sulfide with the hydroxyl group protected as the silyl
ether. However the silyl group was removed by treatment with acid (1 N
HCl) prior to the chromatographic purification.
3-(2-Methylbutylsulfanyl)phenol (Table 6, entries 5-6).8 Yellow oil,
yield 93% 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 7.04 (t, J = 7.9 Hz, 1H), 6.80 (m, 1H), 6.72
(t, J = 2.1 Hz, 1H), 6.53 (m, 1H), 5.90-4.20 (bs, 1H), 2.84 (dd, J = 12.3
Hz and 5.7 Hz, 1H), 2.65 (dd, J = 12.3 Hz and 7.6 Hz, 1H), 1.58 (oct, J =
6.6 Hz, 1H), 1.49-1.40 (m, 1H), 1.22-1.13 (m, 1H), 0.93 (d, J = 6.6 Hz,
3H), 0.82 (d, J = 7.4 Hz, 3H). 13C NMR (CDCl3): δ 155.6, 139.1, 129.8,
120.7, 115.0, 112.5, 40.2, 34.3, 28.7, 18.8, 11.1.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM silica gel used
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM A General, Efficient, and Functional-Group-Tolerant Catalyst System for
the Palladium-Catalyzed Thioetherification of Aryl Bromides and Iodides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Fernandez-Rodriguez, Manuel A.; Hartwig, John F.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2009), 74(4), 1663-1672

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure A for the Synthesis of Aryl,
Alkyl, and Vinyl Sulfides (Tables 3 and 5-10). An oven-dried round-bottom
flask containing a magnetic stir bar was sealed with a rubber septum and
then evacuated and backfilled with argon (the sequence was repeated three
times) with cooling to rt. The round-bottom flask was then charged with
anhydrous potassium phosphate (1.5 equiv), copper(I) iodide (10 mol %),
cis-1,2-cyclohexanediol (20 mol %), and dry DMF (2 mL). The solution
which resulted was stirred for 5-10 min at rt. The reaction mixture
turned a light green color within 3-5 min. The reaction vessel was
evacuated and backfilled with argon one more time before adding the thiol
and the aryl, alkyl, or vinyl iodide. This operation was done to prevent
the formation of disulfides in the presence of oxygen inside the reaction
vessel. The appropriate thiol (1.2 equiv) was added to the reaction
mixture through a rubber septum and the mixture stirred for another 5 min
at rt. The aryl or alkyl or vinyl iodide or bromide (1.0 equiv) of choice
was dissolved in a minimum amount of dry DMFand was added to the
resulting reaction mixture through a rubber septum. The contents of the
reaction mixture were allowed to stir at 30-110 °C for 0.5-15 h depending
on the substrate. The reaction mixture was then cooled to rt and filtered
through a pad of silica gel to remove insoluble residues. The pad of
silica gel was washed ethyl acetate (100 mL). The combined filtrate was
washed with brine (4 x 50 mL), dried (Na2SO4), and concentrated in vacuo
on a rotatory evaporator. The concentrated crude oil was purified by
flash column chromatography on silica gel using the eluent (2-10%) ethyl
acetate and hexane (depending on the substrate) to obtain the pure
product (75-98% yields).
(E)-1,3-Dimethoxy-5-[2-(2-methylbutylsulfanyl)vinyl]benzene (23) (Table
3, Entry 9). General procedure A was followed (4 h). Vinyl iodide 1 (100
mg, 0.34 mmol), 2-methylbutane-1-thiol (42.7 mg, 0.41 mmol), CuI (6.5 mg,
0.034 mmol), 1,2-ciscyclohexanediol (8.0 mg, 0.069 mmol), K3PO4 (109 mg,
0.52 mmol), and DMF (2.0 mL) were stirred at 40-50 °C to obtain the
thioether 23 (84 mg, 93% yield) as a colorless oil. Column chromatography
solvent (3-5% EtOAc in hexane) provided pure 23. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3):
δ 6.74 (1H, d, J=15.6 Hz), δ 6.46 (2H, m), δ 6.42-6.37 (1H, m), δ
6.35-6.33 (1H, m), δ 3.81 (6H, s), δ 2.75 (2H, m), δ 1.80-1.63 (1H, m), δ
1.35-1.25 (2H, m), δ 1.05 (3H, d, J=6.6 Hz), δ 0.95 (3H, t, J=7.4 Hz).
13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ 160.6, 144.8, 139.1, 126.7, 103.5, 98.9, 55.2,
39.7, 34.7, 28.6, 18.8, 11.2. HRMS (ESI) (M + H)+: calcd for C15H23O2S
267.1419, found 267.1415.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

and vinyl sulfides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

Ojas A.; Ara, Shamim; Cook, James M.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2010), 75(11), 3626-3643

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure:
2-(2-Phenylethylsulfanylmethyl)-5-phenylpentanoic Acid Potassium
hexamethyldisilazide (0.5 M in toluene, 20 ml) was added to a solution of
phenethyl mercaptan (0.7 g) in THF (50 ml) at -78°C. and the solution was
stirred for 10 min, then a solution of intermediate 52 (1.4 g) in THF (10
ml) was added dropwise and the mixture was stirred for 3 hours, warming
to room temperature. The mixture was added to water and the solution was
washed with diethyl ether, acidified with acetic acid and extracted with
ether. The ether layer was washed with water and brine, dried and
evaporated and the residue purified by column chromatography, eluting
with 20% ethyl acetate in hexane.
2-(2-Methylpropylsulfanylmethyl)-5-phenylpentanoic Acid From isobutyl
mercaptan (0.9 g) and intermediate 52 (2.8 g), A colourless oil (2.6 g,
93%). TLC R f 0.83 (diethyl ether).

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Step 1. 6-[(1,1-dimethylethyl)thio]-7-(methyloxy)-4(1H)-quinazolinone: To
a solution of 6-iodo-7-(methyloxy)-4(1H)-quinazolinone (1.0 g, 3.3 mmol),
2-methyl-2-propanethiol (0.36 g, 4.0 mmol), Et3N (1.4 mL, 9.9 mmol) in
DMF (5 mL) was added Pd(Ph3P)4 (0.38 g, 0.33 mmol). The reaction mixture
was stirred at 90°C for 1 h. Solvent was removed in vacuo. The crude
material was purified by column chromatography (0 to 5% MeOH/CH2Cl2) to
provide the title compound. Yield 0.90 g, 93%. MS:m/z: 265 [M+H]+.

$DATUM 93
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 121-44-8

$DATUM 4136-95-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 1122-58-3
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Preparation of (-)-cephalotaxyl
(2′R)-2-ethylthiocarbonylmethyl-6,6-dimethyl-2-tetrahydropyrane
carboxylate or 4′-ethylthio-4′-demethoxy-anhydro-homoharringtonine. To a
stirred mixture of 4′-demethyl-anhydro-homoharringtonine (250 mg, 0.486
mmol) resulting from Example 2 in dry dichloromethane (1.8 ml) was added
at 0°C. triethylamine (dried over potassium hydroxide) (68 μl, 0.486
mmol) and 2,4,6-trichlorobenzoyl chloride (76 μl, 0.486 mmol) over a
period of 10 minutes. After stirring at ambient temperature for 2.5 hours
a solution of 4-dimethylaminopyridine (119 mg, 0.973 mmol) and
ethanethiol (72 μl, 0.973 mmol) in dry dichloromethane (0.8 ml) was
added. After stirring at ambient temperature for 15 hours, the reaction
mixture was diluted with dichloromethane (5 ml). The resulting organic
layer was successively washed with water (7 ml), with saturated sodium
hydrogen carbonate solution (7 ml), with brine (7 ml). The resulting
aqueous layer was extracted with dichloromethane (10 ml), then, the
combined organic layers after drying over magnesium sulfate were
evaporated to dryness. The resulting crude product was purified by column
chromatography (silica 15-40 μm (7 g), dichloromethane then
dichloromethane/methanol, 99:1 to 98:2). The expected compound (251 mg,
93%). The product thus obtained showed the following characteristics. IR
(film) (cm-1) 1740 (CO2), 1688 (COS), 1657 (C=C-O), 1504 (Ar), 1223
(C-O), 1142 (C-O), 1078 (C-O), 1037 (C-O), 910. 1H NMR 400 MHz (CDCl3) (δ
ppm, J Hz): 6.64 (1H, s, H-14*), 6.59 (1H, s, H-17*), 5.91 (1H, H-3),
5.90 and 5.85 (2H, 2s, OCH2O), 5.03 (1H, s, H-1), 3.80 (1H, H-4), 3.71
(3H, s, OCH3), 3.14 (2H, m, H-11β+H-8α), 2.88 (1H, m, H-10α), 2.81 (2H,
m, SCH2CH3), 2.61 (2H, m, H-8µ+H-10β), 2.38 (1H, m, H-11µ), 2.35 (1H, d,
JAB=14.8, CHACOS), 2.02 (1H, m, H-6A), 1.91 (1H, m, H-6B), 1.77 (2H, m,
CH2-7), 1.65-1.1 (7H, m, 3×CH2+CHBCOS), 1.20 (3H, t, J=7.4, SCH2CH3),1.14
(3H, s, CH3), 1.02 (3H, s, CH3).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Preparation of ester derivatives of cephalotaxanes for their use in
treatment of cancers, leukemias, parasites including those resistant to
usual chemotherapeutic agents and as reversal agents

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Preparation of (-)-cephalotaxyl
(2'R)-2-ethylthιocarbonylmethy6,6-dιmethy2-tetrahydropyrane carboxylate
or 4'-ethylthio-4'-demethoxy-anhydro-homoharringtonine. To a stirred
mixture of 4'-demethyanhydro-homoharringtonine (250 mg, 0 486 mmol)
resulting from Example 2 in dry dichloromethane (1 8 ml) was added at 0°C
triethylamine (dried over potassium hydroxide) (68 μ l, 0.486 mmol) and
2,4,6-trιchlorobenzoyl chloride (76 μ l, 0.486 mmol) over a period of 10
minutes After stirring at ambient temperature for 2 5 hours a solution of
4-dimethylaminopyridine (1.19 mg, 0.973 mmol) and ethanethiol (72 μ l,
0.973 mmol) in dry dichloromethane (0 8 ml) was added After stirring at
ambient temperature for 15 hours, the reaction mixture was diluted with
dichloromethane (5 ml) The resulting organic layer was successively
washed with water (7 ml), with saturated sodium hydrogen carbonate
solution (7 ml), with brine (7 ml) The resulting aqueous layer was
extracted with dichloromethane (10 ml), then the combined organic layers
after drying over magnesium sulfate were evaporated to dryness The
resulting crude product was purified by column chromatography (silica
15-40 μ m (7g), dichloromethane then dichloromethane / methanol, 99 1 to
98 2) to provide the expected compound. The product thus obtained showed
the following characteristics. Yield 251 mg, 93%. IR (film cm-1 1740
(CO2), 1688 (COS) 1657 (C=C-0), 1504 (Ar), 1223 (C-O), 1142 (C-O), 1078
(C-O), 1037 (C-O) 910; 1H NMR400 MHz () (ό ppm, J Hz) 664 (1H s H-14*),
659 (1H s H-17*), 5.91 (1H H-3) 590 and 5.85 (2H 2s OCH2O) 503 (1H, s,
H-1), 380 (1H, H-4) 3.71 (3H, s, OCH3) 314 (2H , H- 1 1 β + H-8α), 2 88
(1 H, m, H-10α). 2 81 (2H, m, SCH2CH3), 2 61 (2H, m, H-8« I + H-10β), 2
38 (1 H, m, H-11 D), 2 35 (1 H, d, JAB = 14 8, Cfc COS), 2 02 (1 H, m, H-
6A), 1 91 (1 H, m, H-6B), 1 77 (2H, m, CH2-7), 1 65 - 1 1 (7H, m, 3χCH2 +
CHBCQS), 1 20 (3H, t, J = 7.4, SCH2CH3), 1.14 (3H, s, CH3), 1 02 (3H, s,
CH3).

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: ((Alkyl)dithio)carbonyl Chlorides (12). While
these compounds (R = Me, Et, iPr,39 tBu40) have all been described
previously, including purifications by distillation,1,38 the small-scale
procedures for 12c and 12d that follow were newly developed to suit the
needs of this research. A solution of chlorocarbonylsulfenyl chloride (4)
(200 μL, 2.4 mmol) in CHCl3 (2.4 mL) was added to a solution of iPrSH
(198 mg, 2.6 mmol) in CHCl3 (2.4 mL). After 1 h at 25 °C, the mixture was
concentrated. The same procedure was used with tBuSH (234 mg, 2.6 mmol).
12d as a translucent, brown oil (411 mg, 93%). GC-MS: (60 m x 0.25mmID,
DB-5, 50 °C for 1 min, then increase by 15 °C per min until 320 °C; t R =
6.50 min); 1H NMR(300 MHz) δ 1.38 (s, 9 H); 13C NMR(75 MHz) 167.2, 34.4,
29.6 (3 C); GC-MS: (same conditions as for 12c; t R = 6.98 min); HRMS
(CI): m/z [M + NH4 +] calcd for C5H9ClOS2: 202.0122; found: 202.0126; IR
2965 (s), 1785 (vs) cm-1.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Preparation of
Hetero-1,4-naphthoquinones. Equimolar amounts of
2,3-dichloro-1,4-naphthoquinone 1 or monosubstituted naphthoquinone
derivatives 3, 7, and N- or S-nucleophilic compounds 2a-i, 4a-b, and
10a-c in abs. EtOH (50 mL) were stirred at different temperatures using
base, where required. The color of the solution quickly changed and the
extent of the reaction was monitored by TLC. CHCl3 (30 mL) was added to
the reaction mixture. The organic layer was separated and washed with
water (4 x 30 mL), and dried with Na2SO4. The resulting solution was
concentrated in vacuo and the residue was subjected to column
chromatography on silica gel using suitable solvents.Compound 5a was
synthesized from 0.20 g (0.704 mmol)
2-chloro-3-(phenylamino)naphthalene-1,4-dione 3a and 0.182 g (0.704 mmol)
hexadecanethiol 4a using triethylamine as base according to the general
procedure. Compound 6b was synthesized by the reaction of 0.1 g (0.331
mmol) 2-chloro-3-((4-fluorophenyl)amino)naphthalene-1,4-dione 3b with
0.095 g (0.331 mmol) octadecanthiol 4b and using triethylamine as base
according to the general procedure. Compound 6b as red color, yield 93%.
m.p. 86-87°C. IR (KBr): ν = 3296 (N-H), 3051 (C-Harom.), 2914, 2849
(C-Haliph.), 1664, 1631 (C=O), 1589,1541 (C=C). -1H-NMR (499.74 MHz,
CDCl3): δ = 0.79-0.83 (t, 3H, J= 6.83 Hz, CH3), 1.09-1.32, 1.50-1.57 (m,
32H, CH2), 2.50-2.53 (t, 2H, J= 7.32 Hz,S-CH2), 7.67 (bs, 1H, NH),
6.91-6.94 (m, 2H, CHarom), 6.95-6.97 (m, 2H, Hz, CHarom), 7.56 (t, 1H, J=
7.57 Hz, CHnapht), 7.67 (t, 1H, J= 7.57 Hz, CHnapht), 7.98 (d, 1H, J=
7.56 Hz, CHnapht), 8.07 (d, 1H, J= 7.56 Hz, CHnapht). -13C-NMR (125.66
MHz, CDCl3): δ = 14.3 (-CH3), 22.9, 28.8, 29.5, 30.0, 32.1 (-CH2-),
34.2(SCH2-), 115.4, 124.6 (CHarom), 117.9 (S-Cnapht), 130.8 (-NH-Cnapht),
126.8, 127.1, 132.9, 133.7 (CHnapht), 134.7, 134.8(Cnapht), 145.6 (NH-C),
159.1-161.1 (d, F-Carom), 180.5, 181.1 (C=O). -MS (+ESI): m/z = 552[M]+,
C34H46FNO2S, (551.32). Calcd., %: C 74.01; H 8.40; N 2.54; S 5.81 Found,
%: C 74.38; H 9.02; N 2.74; S 5.70.

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Preparation of
Hetero-1,4-naphthoquinones. Equimolar amounts of
2,3-dichloro-1,4-naphthoquinone 1 or monosubstituted naphthoquinone
derivatives 3, 7, and N- or S-nucleophilic compounds 2a-i, 4a-b, and
10a-c in abs. EtOH (50 mL) were stirred at different temperatures using
base, where required. The color of the solution quickly changed and the
extent of the reaction was monitored by TLC. CHCl3 (30 mL) was added to
the reaction mixture. The organic layer was separated and washed with
water (4 x 30 mL), and dried with Na2SO4. The resulting solution was
concentrated in vacuo and the residue was subjected to column
chromatography on silica gel using suitable solvents.Compound 5a was
synthesized from 0.20 g (0.704 mmol)
2-chloro-3-(phenylamino)naphthalene-1,4-dione 3a and 0.182 g (0.704 mmol)
hexadecanethiol 4a using triethylamine as base according to the general
procedure. Compound 5b was synthesized by the reaction of 0.2 g (0.662
mmol) 2-chloro-3-((4-fluorophenyl)amino)naphthalene-1,4-dione 3b with
0.171 g (0.662 mmol) hexadecanthiol 4a and using triethylamine as base
according to the general procedure. Compound 5b as red color, yield 93%.
m.p. 79-80°C. IR (KBr): ν = 3296 (N-H), 3051 (C-Harom.), 2915, 2849
(C-Haliph.), 1665, 1631 (C=O), 1556 (C=C).-1H-NMR (499.74 MHz, CDCl3): δ
= 0.79-0.82 (t, 3H, J= 6.83 Hz, CH3), 1.09-1.33, 1.49-1.57 (m, 28H, CH2),
2.50-2.53 (t, 2H, J= 7.32 Hz,S-CH2), 7.65 (bs, 1H, NH), 6.91-6.94 (m, 2H,
CHarom), 6.95-6.97 (m, 2H, Hz, CHarom), 7.57 (t, 1H, J= 7.56 Hz,
CHnapht), 7.67 (t, 1H, J= 7.56 Hz, CHnapht), 7.98 (d, 1H, J= 7.08 Hz,
CHnapht), 8.08 (d, 1H, J= 7.08 Hz, CHnapht).-13C-NMR (125.66 MHz, CDCl3):
δ = 13.0 (-CH3), 21.7, 27.6, 28.3, 28.7, 30.9 (-CH2-), 33.0 (SCH2-),
114.1, 123.6 (CHarom), 116.7 (S-Cnapht), 129.5 (-NH-Cnapht), 125.6,
125.8, 131.7, 132.5, (CHnapht), 133.5, 133.6 (Cnapht), 144.4 (NH-C),
157.9-159.8 (d, F-Carom), 179.3, 179.9(C=O).-MS (+ESI): m/z = 524[M]+,
C32H42FNO2S, (523.74). Calcd., %: C 73.38; H 8.08; N 2.67; S 6.12 Found,
%: C 73.66; H 8.08; N 2.68; S % 6.18.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Example 132 To a volume of DMF (10 mL) saturated with excess methanethiol
at -78 °C was added sodium hydride (60% suspension in mineral oil, 56 mg,
1.39 mmol). The mixture was warmed to 0 °C and stirred for 30 minutes.
The mixture was then added to a solution of Example 131 (394 mg, 0.93
mmol) in DMF (2 mL) and was stirred at 0 °C for 30 minutes. The solvent
was evaporated under high vacuum. The residue was neutralized with
concentrated HCl and the solvent was evaporated. The residue was diluted
with CH2Cl2 and was washed with saturated aqueous NaHCO3 and H2O5 dried
over MgSO4, and evaporated. Purification by flash column chromatography
(gradient, straight EtOAc to EtOAc/MeOH, 10:1) gave of Example 132.
Example 132 (200 mg, 0.46 mmol) was converted to the HCl salt by treating
a solution of Example 132 in MeOH with excess 4N HCl in dioxane and then
by evaporating the solvent to give 223 mg (96% yield). yield 374 mg
(93%). 1H NMR (CD3OD) δ 2.14 (s, 3 Η), 2.30-2.39 (m, 2 Η), 2.70 (t, J =
6.6 Hz, 2 Η), 4.78 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 2 Η), 5.01 (q, J = 8.7 Hz, 2 Η), 6.05
(s, 2 Η), 7.62-7.75 (m, 2 Η), 7.76 (d, J = 7.5 Hz, 1 Η), 7.99-8.04 (m, 2
Η), 8.71 (d, J = 6.6 Hz, 1 Η), 9.09 (s, 1 H); IR (KBr, cm-1)
3412,2762,1760,1655,1624, 1519, 1264,1169, 1119, 834, 752; MS m/e 436
(MH+).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM product further converted into hydrochloric acid salt
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Pyruvaldehyde Diethylthioacetal (5i). Fifty millimoles of 1,1-
dichloroacetone was added dropwise to a 50 mL slurry of dried acetone
containing 5 g of powdered potassium carbonate and 120 mmol of ethyl
mercaptan. The reaction mixture was allowed to stir at room temperature
for 24 h and the dithioacetal isolated , 6.8 g, 93% yield by vacuum
distillation as a slightly yellow oil (bp 138-139 °C; 0.7 mmHg). 1H NMR
(CDCl3) δ 1.21 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 6H), 2.32 (s, 3H), 2.53 (dq, J = 12.6, 7.4
Hz, 2H), 2.61 (dq, J = 12.6, 7.4 Hz, 2H), 4.34 (s, 1H). 13C NMR (CDCl3) δ
14.35, 25.01, 25.85, 58.06, 201.10. Anal. Calcd for C7H14OS2: C, 47.15;
H, 7.91. Found: C, 47.12; H, 7.80.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Thioacetalization and Transthioacetalization;
General Procedure To a stirred mixture of a carbonyl compound (1 mmol) or
an acetal (1 mmol) and alkyl thiol (2.2 mmol) or ethane dithiol (1.2
mmol) in CH2Cl2 (10 mL), activated NaHSO4·SiO2 (200 mg) was added at r.t.
The progress of the reaction was monitored by TLC. After completion of
the reaction, the mixture was filtered and the filtrate was concentrated.
The residue was subjected to column chromatography over silica gel and
the column was eluted with EtOAc-hexane (1:4) to afford pure thioacetal.
The spectral and analytical data of the unknown compound are given below.
Compound 2z, yield 93%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Studies on novel synthetic methodologies. Part 39. Simple, mild and
efficient thioacetalization and transthioacetalization of carbonyl
compounds and deprotection of thioacetals: unique role of thiols in the
selectivity of thioacetalization
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Synthetic Procedure: Typically, 10 mg
of H2SO4-SiO2 (0.04 mmol) was added to the solution of
3,4,6-tri-O-benzyl-D-glucal (0.10 mmol, 40 mg) in dichloromethane (3 mL),
and then was added n-butyl alcohol (1a, 36 μL, 0.40 mmol). The reaction
mixture was stirred for 1.2 h at rt. After the reaction was completed,
the reaction mixture was filtered and the catalyst was washed with
dichloromethane. The organic phase was combined and condensed under
vacuum to get crude product, which was purified by silica gel column
chromatography (petroleum ether/EtOAc = 20/1) to get 1b as yellow syrup
in an 87% yield (32.0 mg, α:β = 7.1:1). Product, yield 93%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM green chemistry, solid-supported catalyst, stereoselective, H2SO4
supported on SiO2 used, Ferrier rearrangement, alpha:beta 8.7:1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM A Facile H2SO4-SiO2-Catalyzed Ferrier Rearrangement of
3,4,6-Tri-O-benzyl-d-glucal
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Zhang, Jianbo; Zhang, Bo; Zhou, Jiafen; Chen, Heshan; Li, Juan; Yang,
Guofang; Wang, Zhongfu; Tang, Jie
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Carbohydrate Chemistry (2013), 32(5-6), 380-391

$DATUM N-phenydiethylthiolmaleimide (3) To a solution of N-phenydibromomaleimide
2 (237 mg, 0.72 mmol) in DCM (30 mL) were added ethanethiol (0.11 mL,
1.50 mmol) and NEt3(0.21 mL, 1.50 mmol) and the mixture was stirred for
15 min at room temperature and then concentrated to dryness. The crude
residue was purified by flash chromatography to give the desired product.
Yield (195 mg g, 0.66 mmol, 93 %). Rf 0.36 (10% EtOAc/petroleum ether);
vmax (cm-1) 2965, 2926, 2851, 1706, 1598, 1501, 1371; δΗ (CDCl3, 600MHz)
7.48-7.44 (2H, m, ArH), 7.37-7.33 (3H, m, ArH), 3,37 (4H, q, J = 1 A Hz,
CH3CH2S), 1.38 (6H, t, J = 1 A Hz, CH3CH2S); 6C (CDCl3, 150 MHz) 165.5,
135.7, 131.6, 129.2, 128.0, 126.2, 26.5, 15.8; HRMS (EI) calculated for
C14H15O2NS2 293.05387, observed 293.05403.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM B. 5-CH2OBn substituted thiopyranoside 5-CH2OBn substituted
thiopyranoside 20. To a solution of pyran S108 (0.27 g, 1.0 mmol) in
CH2Cl2 (10 mL) was added ethanethiol (0.15 mL, 2.0 mmol) followed by
p-toluenesulfonic acid monohydrate (0.39 g, 2.0 mmol). After 3 h, the
solution was washed with saturated aqueous NaHCO3 (20 mL), and the
aqueous layer was extracted with CH2Cl2 (3 x 20 mL). The combined organic
layers were dried over Na2SO4 and concentrated in vacuo. The resulting
yellow oil was purified by flash chromatography (3:1 hexanes:EtOAc) to
afford thiopyranoside 20 as a clear oil (0.25 g, 93%). 1H NMR (500 MHz,
CDCl3; compound isolated as a 62:38 mixture of anomers; the major anomer
is denoted by *) δ 7.25-7.35 (m, 5H* + 5H), 5.42 (d, J = 5.0 Hz, 1H*),
4.67 (m, 2H* + 3H), 4.32 (m, 1H*), 3.64 (m, 2H), 3.47 (m, 2H* + 1H),
2.5-2.8 (m, 2H* + 2H), 1.99 (m, 1H*), 1.92 (m, 1H), 1.79 (m, 2H* + 1H),
1.61 (m, 3H* + 2H), 1.45 (m, 2H), 1.29 (m, 3H* + 3H); 13C NMR (125 MHz,
CDCl3; compound isolated as a 62:38 mixture of anomers; the major anomer
is denoted by *) δ 138.51, 138.46*, 128.40, 128.36*, 127.7*, 127.61,
127.55*, 127.5, 82.5, 81.3*, 78.1, 73.7, 73.5, 73.4*, 73.3*, 67.7*, 31.6,
30.2*, 27.9*, 27.7, 24.7, 24.3*, 23.9, 19.2*, 15.3, 15.1*; IR (thin film)
3031, 2938, 2863, 1452, 1374 cm-1; HRMS (ESI) m / z calcd for C15H22O2SNa
(M + Na)+ 289.1238, found 289.1238. Anal. Calcd for C15H22O2S: C, 67.63;
H, 8.32. Found: C, 67.72; H, 8.31.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Erosion of Stereochemical Control with Increasing Nucleophilicity:

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 1314-56-3
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: S,S-Thioacetalization of carbonyl compounds
(general procedure): A mixture of carbonyl compounds (2 mmol), dithiol
(2.2 mmol) or thiol (4.4 mmol) and P2O5/SiO2 (5 mg) was stirred at
ambient temperature. After completion of reaction as checked by TLC, it
was diluted with n-hexane and the catalyst was filtered off. The filtrate
solution (50 ml) was washed with aqueous 10% NaOH (2 x 10 ml) solution
and then dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The solvent was evaporated by
rotary evaporator and the crude product was purified through a column of
silica gel (n-hexane:EtOAc, 80:20) to obtain the pure product. Entry 8d,
yield 92%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM solid-supported catalyst, silica support used, reusable catalyst, no
solvent
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Silica gel-supported phosphorus pentoxide: a reusable catalyst for
S,S-acetalization of carbonyl groups under ambient conditions
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Shaterian, Hamid Reza; Azizi, Kobra; Fahimi, Nafiseh
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Sulfur Chemistry (2011), 32(1), 85-91

$DATUM 1314-56-3
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: S,S-Thioacetalization of carbonyl compounds
(general procedure): A mixture of carbonyl compounds (2 mmol), dithiol
(2.2 mmol) or thiol (4.4 mmol) and P2O5/SiO2 (5 mg) was stirred at
ambient temperature. After completion of reaction as checked by TLC, it
was diluted with n-hexane and the catalyst was filtered off. The filtrate
solution (50 ml) was washed with aqueous 10% NaOH (2 x 10 ml) solution
and then dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The solvent was evaporated by
rotary evaporator and the crude product was purified through a column of
silica gel (n-hexane:EtOAc, 80:20) to obtain the pure product. Entry 12d,
yield 92%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM solid-supported catalyst, silica support used, reusable catalyst, no
solvent
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Silica gel-supported phosphorus pentoxide: a reusable catalyst for
S,S-acetalization of carbonyl groups under ambient conditions
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Shaterian, Hamid Reza; Azizi, Kobra; Fahimi, Nafiseh
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Sulfur Chemistry (2011), 32(1), 85-91

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Procedure for Aromatic-Aromatic and
Aromatic-Aliphatic Disulfides as Illustrated for Entry 1 in Table 2. To a
stirred solution of 1-chlorobenzotriazole (0.61 g, 4 mmol) and
benzotriazole (0.32 g, 2 0.7 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (30 mL) under N2 at -78 °C
was added dropwise a solution of p-methoxybenzenethiol as R1SH (0.37 g,
2.7 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (2 mL). The solution was allowed to stir for 2 h with
slow warming to -20 °C. 1-Propanethiol as R2SH (0.30 g, 4 mmol) in CH2Cl2
(2 mL) was then added slowly at -20 °C and the solution stirred at 0 °C
for 30 min. The reaction was then quenched with a solution of Na2S2O3
(0.50 g in 10 mL water) together with saturated aqueous NaHCO3 (20 mL),
with rapid stirring at 0 °C for 20 min before being extracted with CH2Cl2
(3 100 mL). The combined organic extracts were dried over anhydrous
MgSO4, filtered, and evaporated under reduced pressure. The crude
material was purified by silica gel column chromatography using light
petroleum/EtOAc mixtures to afford p-methoxyphenyl 1-propyl disulfide
(entry 1, 0.515 g, 2.4 mmol, 89%) as a pale-yellow oil. t-Butyl 2-pyridyl
disulfide (entry 7)30 Entry 7 (0.368 g, 92%) was obtained as a clear oil.
IR (CHCl3): νmax 479 cm-1 (S-S). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 1.34 (s, 3H),
7.04 (m, 1H), 7.61 (td, J = 7.6 Hz, 1.6 Hz, 1H), 7.79 (m, 1H), 8.42 (m,
1H). 13C NMR (100.6 MHz, CDCl3): δ 29.8, 49.2, 119.7, 120.3 , 136.7,
149.1, 161.7. HRMS: calcd for C9H13NS2 (M)+, 199.0489; found 199.0491.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM green chemistry (- reagent)
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Inexpensive, one-pot synthesis of unsymmetrical disulfides using
1-chlorobenzotriazole
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Hunter, Roger; Caira, Mino; Stellenboom, Nashia
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2006), 71(21), 8268-8271

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Synthesis of
Benzyl/Allyl Sulfides and Thiocyanates 3 (Entries 1-22) Carbonyl compound
1 (2 mmol) and NaBH4 (2 mmol) were taken in [bmim]BF4 (5 mL), and the
reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 0.5-3 h (monitored
by TLC for the complete reduction of 1) followed by addition of molecular
iodine (0.2 mmol) and stirring at rt for 0.5 h. Then, PhSH/n-BuSH (2
mmol) or NH4SCN (2 mmol) was added, and the reaction mixture was stirred
at rt for 1-2 h (Table 2). After completion of the reaction as indicated
by TLC, water (10 mL) was added and the aqueous layer was separated from
the residue. The residue was subjected to silica-gel column
chromatography using EtOAc-hexane (1:3) as eluent to obtain a sample of
analytically pure 3. On the other hand, dichloromethane (15 mL) was added
to the aqueous layer containing the IL and stirred for 10 min. The
dichloromethane layer was separated and evaporated to afford the recycled
[(bmim)BF4], which was used in susequent runs without further
purification. Butyl(1-(4-methoxyphenyl)ethyl)sulfane (Table 2, entry 5).
Yield: 0.41 g (2 mmol, 92%); colorless liquid. IR (neat, cm-1): 3052,
2901, 1605, 1580, 1475, 1435, 820;1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3/TMS): δ 0.89 (t,
J = 7.1 Hz, 3 H, Me), 1.33-1.55 (m, 4 H, 2 x CH2), 1.65 (d, J = 7.0 Hz, 3
H, Me), 2.43 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 2 H, SCH2), 3.73 (s, 3 H, OMe), 3.88 (q, J =
7.0 Hz, 1 H, SCH), 6.79 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 2 Harom), 7.07-7.49 (d, J = 8.6
Hz, 2 Harom);13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3/TMS): δ 14.2, 22.6, 24.0, 29.4,
31.3, 42.0, 54.8, 127.0, 128.6, 129.6, 138.1; MS (EI): m/z= 224 [M+].
Anal. calcd. for C13H20OS: C, 69.59; H, 8.98. Found: C, 69.78; H, 8.74.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM green chemistry-solvent, global reaction time: 4.5h, ionic liquid used,
in-situ generated reactant in stage 1, reaction is not sensitive to air
and moisture
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM One-pot reductive sulfenylation and thiocyanation of carbonyl compounds
in ionic liquid media
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Yadav, Lal Dhar S.; Kapoor, Ritu
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthetic Communications (2011), 41(1), 100-112

$DATUM 68-12-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-99-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM 6-chloro-2-(propylthio)-N-(tetrahydro-2H-pyran-4-yl)nicotinamide Sodium
hexamethyldisilazide (1M in THF) (9 mL, 9 mmol) was added to a solution
of 1-propanethiol (0.684 g, 9 mmol) in DMF (14 mL) under N2. This
solution was added to a solution of
2,6-dichloro-N-(tetrahydro-2H-pyran-4-yl)nicotinamide (2.93 g, 9 mmol) in
DMF (14 mL) under N2 and stirred for 18 hours. The reaction mixture was
diluted with EtOAc (200 mL), and washed sequentially with water (50 mL)
and saturated brine (50 mL). The organic layer was dried over MgSO4,
filtered and evaporated to afford crude product. The crude product was
purified by flash silica chromatography, elution gradient 0 to 50% EtOAc
in DCM. Pure fractions were evaporated to dryness to afford
2,6-dichloro-N-(tetrahydro-2H-pyran-4-yl)nicotinamide (2.60 g, 92%) as a
white solid. 1H NMR (400.13 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ0.97 (3H, t), 1.45-1.55 (2H,
m), 1.59-1.68 (2H, m), 1.75-1.79 (2H, m), 3.04 (2H, t), 3.34-3.43 (2H,
m), 3.84-3.96 (3H, m), 7.29 (1H, d), 7.78 (1H, d), 8.49 (1H, d); m/z
(ESI+) (M+H)+)+=315; HPLC tR=2.17 min
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM regioselective
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Preparation of pyridine derivatives as inhibitors of human 11β
hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase type 1 enzyme
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM McCoull, William; Packer, Martin; Scott, James Stewart; Whittamore, Paul
Robert Owen
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2008053194 A2 2008-05-08

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for reaction of thiols
(2b-n) with N-benzylidene-benzamide (1a): To a flame-dried reaction tube
with septa and stir bar was added N-acyl imine (1a) (0.1 mmol) and
(R)-TRIP-PA catalyst, (R)-PA-5 (2 mol %). The tube was evacuated and
filled with argon. Dry toluene (1.0 mL) was added to the mixture,
followed by thiol, 2b-n (0.12 mmol) via syringe. The reaction was stirred
at room temperature for 10 minutes. The crude product was purified
directly by flash column chromatography (hexane: ethyl acetate = 2:1) to
give the corresponding chiral N,S-acetal product. The ee values of the
products were determined by chiral HPLC analysis after the products were
purified. N-[(4-Methoxy-phenylsulfanyl)-phenyl-methyl]-benzamide (4b)
N-(Isobutylsulfanyl-phenyl-methyl)-benzamide (4i) The reaction was
performed according to an altered general procedure using 5 mol % of PA5
to obtain a white solid, 27.5 mg, 92% yield, 95% ee. Mp: 129.2-130.1°C.
HPLC analysis: Chiralcel OD-H (hexane/iPrOH = 90/10, 1.0 mL/min), t
r-major 7.09 min, t r-minor 5.97 min. [α]20 D = -22.5° (c = 0.425,
CHCl3). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.73 (d, 2H, J = 8 Hz), 7.46-7.34 (m,
5H), 7.29- 7.17 (m, 3H), 6.63 (d, 1H, J = 8.0 Hz), 6.39 (d, 1H, J = 8.0
Hz), 2.61 (dd, 1H, J = 12.4 Hz, J = 6.4 Hz), 2.39 (dd, 1H, J = 12.4 Hz, J
= 7.2 Hz), 1.89-1.79 (m, 1H), 0.93 (d, 3H, J = 2.0 Hz), 0.91 (d, 3H, J =
2.0 Hz). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3) δ 166.56, 139.64, 134.02, 132.06,
128.95, 128.88, 128.40, 127.19, 126.69, 57.56, 40.87, 28.86, 22.43,
22.04. HRMS (ESI) calcd for C18H21NOS ([M+Na]+ ) m/z 322.12361, found
322.12399.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 110-71-4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Coupling of
Functionalized Aryl Bromides and Iodides with Aliphatic and Aromatic
Thiols. The appropriate quantity of stock solution A or B was added to a
4 mL vial containing the aryl bromide or iodide (1.00 mmol) and LiHMDS or
Cs2CO3 (2.4 mmol) as base, unless otherwise stated, in DME (1.5 mL). The
thiol (1.00 mmol) was then added and the vial was sealed with a cap
containing a PTFE septum. The mixture was heated at the temperature
indicated in Tables 6 and 7 until the aryl halide was consumed, as
determined by GC. Silica gel (0.5 g) was added, and the solvents were
evaporated under reduced pressure. The crude residue was purified by
column chromatography on silica gel with hexane or a mixture of hexane
and ethyl acetate as eluent. Aryl sulfides were isolated in the yields
reported in Tables 6 and 7. Reactions of haloarenes bearing aromatic or
aliphatic hydroxyl groups and LiHMDS as base initially form the
corresponding sulfide with the hydroxyl group protected as the silyl
ether. However the silyl group was removed by treatment with acid (1 N
HCl) prior to the chromatographic purification.
N-(4-(2-Methylbutylsulfanyl)phenyl) acetamide (Table 6, entry 13). White
solid, yield 92% 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 7.66 (bs, 1H), 7.34 (d, J = 8.4 Hz,
2H), 7.20 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 2H), 2.81 (dd, J = 5.8 Hz and 12.6 Hz, 1H),
2.62 (dd, J = 7.6 Hz and 12.6 Hz, 1H), 2.07 (s, 3H), 1.54 (oct, J = 6.6
Hz, 1H), 1.48-1.40 (m, 1H), 1.21-1.13 (m, 1H), 0.92 (d, J = 6.6 Hz, 3H),
0.81 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 3H). 13C NMR (CDCl3): δ 168.5, 136.0, 132.4, 130.2
(2C), 120.4 (2C), 41.6, 34.4, 28.6, 24.4, 18.7, 11.1. Elem. Anal. Calcd
for C13H19NOS: C, 65.78; H, 8.07; N, 5.90. Found: C, 65.57; H, 7.92; N,
5.91.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM silica gel used
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM A General, Efficient, and Functional-Group-Tolerant Catalyst System for
the Palladium-Catalyzed Thioetherification of Aryl Bromides and Iodides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Fernandez-Rodriguez, Manuel A.; Hartwig, John F.

$DATUM 109-63-7
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 108-88-3
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Typical Procedure for the Synthesis of
3-Isopropenyl-6-methyl-2-phenyltetrahydrothiopyran (3a, Table 1).
6-Methyl-hept-5-ene-2-thiol (86 mg, 0.6 mmol) in 2 mL of toluene was
added dropwise to a stirring mixture of benzaldehyde (53 mg, 0.5 mmol),
boron trifluoride etherate (63 μL, 0.5 mmol), and toluene (2 mL) at 0°C.
The stirring was continued at the same temperature for 30 min, and then
the mixture was poured into saturated NaHCO3 (5 mL). The reaction mixture
was extracted with ethyl acetate and then washed with brine and water.
The organic layers were collected, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and
concentrated. Then the resultant crude residue was purified by column
chromatography over silica gel (petroleum ether/ EtOAc 98:2).
Tetrahydro-6-methyl-3-(prop-1-en-2-yl)-2-styryl-2H-thiopyran (3h):
colorless liquid (119 mg, 92%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 1.20 (d, J= 6.4
Hz, 3 H), 1.47 (ddd, J= 11.2, 10.8, and 10.0 Hz, 1 H), 1.55-1.67 (m, 1
H), 1.63 (s, 3 H), 1.83 (dt, J= 10.0 and 2.8 Hz, 1 H), 2.02-2.08 (m, 1
H), 2.27 (dt, J= 11.2 and 2.8 Hz, 1 H), 2.92- 2.98 (m, 1 H), 3.57 (t, J=
10.0 Hz, 1 H), 4.70-4.80 (m, 2 H), 6.99 (dd, J= 15.6 and 8.8 Hz, 1 H),
6.51(d, J= 15.6 Hz, 1 H), 7.18-7.22 (m, 2 H), 7.25-7.33 (m, 3 H); 13C NMR
(100 MHz, CDCl3) δ 19.7, 21.3, 32.9, 36.9, 38.7, 48.0, 52.2, 112.1,
126.5, 127.6, 128.6, 128.9, 132.0, 137.1, 147.9; IR (KBr, neat) 2960,
2922, 1644, 1448, 1374, 1159, 1028, 890 cm-1; HRMS (APCI) calcd for
C17H22S (M + H)+ requires 259.1515, found 259.1518.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM stereoselective, Prins cyclization
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Diastereoselective Synthesis of Substituted Tetrahydrothiopyrans via
(3,5)-Thionium-Ene Cyclization Reaction
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Bondalapati, Somasekhar; Gogoi, Paramartha; Indukuri, Kiran; Saikia, Anil
K.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2012), 77(5), 2508-2512

$DTYPE RXN:RCT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 1067170-12-0
$DTYPE RXN:RCT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 1067170-18-6
$DTYPE RXN:PRO(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 1067170-42-6
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAS_Reaction_Number
$DATUM 31-260-CAS-10795721
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STEPS
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES
$DATUM 2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 92
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 1310-58-3
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 64-17-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The synthesis of trifluoromethylvinyl sulfides
(general procedure). Ethanol (5 mL), KOH (0.34 g, 5.5 mmol), and thiol (6
mmol) were placed in a 25-mL round-bottom flask, and this was stirred for
5 min until complete dissolution of KOH. Then, a solution of the
corresponding styrenes 1 or 2 (5 mmol) in ethanol (5 mL) was added with
vigorous stirring, and the reaction mixture was refluxed for 5-10 min
(TLC monitoring). The reaction mixture was poured in water (100 mL),
extracted with dichloromethane (3×100 mL). The combined extract was
washed with brine and dried with Na2SO4. Dichloromethane was removed in
vacuo, the residue was dissolved in hexane or in the appropriate
hexane-dichloromethane mixture and run through a short layer of silica
gel. Attempted chromatographic separation of isomeric of alkenes failed.
The product was obtained from 1a.
2-[(1Z)-2-(Ethylthio)-3,3,3-trifluoro-1-propenyl]pyridine (3g) was
obtained from 1g. The yield was 92%, colorless oil. Ratio: 1:0. Found
(%): C 51.29; H 4.33. C10H10F3NS. Calculated (%): C, 51.49; H 4.32. IR,
ν/cm-1: 1610 (C═C). 1H NMR (CDCl3), δ: 1.19 (t, 3 H, SCH2CH3, J = 7.4
Hz); 2.81 (q, 2 H, SCH2CH3, J = 7.4 Hz); 7.21-7.24 (m, 1 H, Py); 7.47 (s,
1 H, CH═CCF3); 7.70 (td, 1 H, Py, J = 7.7 Hz, J = 1.7 Hz); 7.95 (d, 1 H,
Py, J = 7.7 Hz); 8.64-8.67 (m, 1 H, Py). 13C NMR (CDCl3), δ: 14.2
(SCH2CH3); 28.2 (SCH2CH3); 123.2 (q, CF3, J = 274.4 Hz); 127.9 (q, C-CF3,
J = 31.5 Hz); 136.7 (q, CH═CCF3, J = 5.9 Hz); 123.3, 125.3, 136.1, 149.5,
152.9 (Py).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM regioselective, stereoselective
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM New approach to the synthesis of (trifluoromethyl)vinyl sulfides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Muzalevskiy, V. M.; Shastin, A. V.; Balenkova, E. S.; Nenajdenko, V. G.
